title: Neil deGrasse Tyson talks misconduct claims: 'I learned that I had friends in times of need'
text:
CLOSE Fox, National Geographic and the producers of the show ‘Cosmos’ have announced an investigation into allegations of sexual misconduct against their host, famed astrophysicist Neil deGrasse Tyson. Susana Victoria Perez has more. Buzz60

Neil deGrasse Tyson is on a media tour to promote his new book, but every talk show he stopped by kicked off by addressing the elephant in the room – his sexual misconduct allegations.

In Tyson's appearance on "The Late Show with Stephen Colbert" on Monday, the late night host asked him what he learned about his experience being in the midst of his own #MeToo movement.

In 2018 two women, identified as working with Tyson or in his scientific field, accused him of inappropriate sexual behavior.

Tyson denied the allegations at the time, and after investigations concluded, the astrophysicist was able to keep his job at the New York's American Museum of Natural History.

The "Cosmos" host told Colbert about the importance of support he's been receiving.

"I learned that I had friends in times of need, and in a time of stress, that's what I learned from this year," Tyson said. "As a scientist, I spend most of my time thinking objectively about the world, thinking a little less about emotion about feelings and when I needed it most, people were there for me: friends, family, fans."

The "Star Talk" host echoed the same sentiment on "The View" and "CBS This Morning."

CBS host Anthony Mason also asked Tyson what he learned from his year long experience.

"I learned to care about the support I’ve received, from friends, family, a fan base that was there throughout the entire time and a lot of that fan base was sort of represented spiritually and emotionally and intellectually in this collection of letters where it's people sharing their deepest issues angst about the world," Tyson said referencing his new book "Letters from an Astrophysicist." "All I'm saying is in the past year I learned to value that more than ever before."

Neil deGrasse Tyson stops by talk shows to promote new book and discusses sexual misconduct allegations. (Photo: Michael Loccisano, Getty Images for Webby Awards)

On "The View," Tyson was asked about the challenges he's faced in the past year and, again, he noted his excitement for being able to focus his energy back on the work he was doing.

"I see myself as servant to the public's appetite for learning about the universe, and it's what I do, it's all I do and so to get back to work and maintain that has been good for me," Tyson said. "But in there has been the support of friends and family and fans even I have not fully appreciated how important that was as a buoyant force in ones life."
